Package com.visionspace.taskmanager.impl.launcher

Class TaskLauncher

java.lang.Object
com.visionspace.taskmanager.impl.launcher.TaskLauncher
public class TaskLauncher
extends java.lang.Object
Class responsible for launching the tasks that are registered in a TaskStore.

The task launcher becomes active only when its start() method is invoked; this makes the launcher to schedule all the tasks in QUEUED state and to start listening for subsequent queued tasks in the store, scheduling tasks as they are queued.

Queued tasks are submitted to a ScheduledExecutorService; when they are actually executed, the launcher first attempts to claim them, and executes the task only if it was claimed. A task may not be claimed if it changed its state after being scheduled, e.g., it was cancelled or claimed by a replica launcher.

A ScheduledExecutorService with a fixed size thread pool and un unbound work queue is used. This means that there may be up to a fixed number of tasks running concurrently, with execution requests having to wait for running tasks to finish in case all worker threads are busy; in this scenario, scheduled won't start at their intended time. In order to mitigate this, tasks may specify a maximum wait time (see TaskDescriptor.getMaxWaitTimeMillis()), being rejected in case they wait for more than this time. In a real live scenario, should this situation happen then capacity may be increased by adding additional launcher JVMs.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    void close​(long timeout, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
    Closes this launcher by cancelling any running tasks and stopping listening for new tasks.
    void start()
    Starts the task launcher by scheduling the tasks that are in QUEUED state and listening for new queued tasks.

  • Constructor Details

    • TaskLauncher

      public TaskLauncher​(TaskStore taskStore, int maxTasks)
      Constructor.
      Parameters:
      taskStore - The task store to use.
      maxTasks - Maximum number of concurrent tasks, if this limit is reached and additional tasks are submitted they wait for running tasks to complete prior to starting.

  • Method Details

    • start

      public void start()
      Starts the task launcher by scheduling the tasks that are in QUEUED state and listening for new queued tasks.

    • close

      public void close​(long timeout, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit) throws java.lang.InterruptedException
      Closes this launcher by cancelling any running tasks and stopping listening for new tasks.
      Parameters:
      timeout - The maximum time to wait for running tasks to complete.
      unit - The unit for the timeout above.
      Throws:
      java.lang.InterruptedException
